Testing Criteria: Information (e.g., policies and/or procedures) that is utilized to perform testing, review and authorization of changes and/or emergency changes.
Key Considerations for Design:
1. Policies should be be formalised and applicable for the current audit period. If not flag as an exception. 

2. Policies should provide sufficient detail over the standard operating procedures and should be made readily available to employees
Example response Design: Inspected a copy of 'change enablement policy' and 'change management standard operating procedures' approved by the CIO on xx/xx/2024
Tailored Procedure - Implementation / Ev:
Inspect the respective policy that outlines standard operating procedures for the change process.

Validate the policy provides sufficient detail over the change process, to the extent that requirements for testing, approval, types of change and implementation is outlined within.
Key Considerations for Implementation:
1. The change policy must be applicable to the system being assessed with sufficient detail to ensure that standard practices are outlined. 

2. Policies should be approved or reviewed in within 2 years of the audit period. Consider the policy outdated if it has not been reviewed in 2 years.
Example Response implementation:
PwC inspected the change enablement policy on the XX/XX/2024. It was noted that version 4 policy provides a comprehensive overview of the change process and is used within the operation of the control.

The policy was reveiewed Mr Smith on the XX/XX/2024 to validate the use of the policy within FY24 .Mr Smith is the CIO and therefore an appropriate person to provide approval for the policy.

Testing Criteria: How and who is responsible for making changes to application code (e.g. versions) configuration (e.g., settings or tolerances that can be made via the application without requiring amendments to code) and whether such changes are subject to the same change control processes.
Key Considerations for Design:
1. Clearly define who is responsible for making changes to application code and configuration settings. This includes developers, system administrators, and configuration managers.

2. Consider who has access to the functional code of the underlying system and whether this is restricted to a subset of individuals or whether the application is hosted by an external vendor. 

3. Understand whether changes to code or configuration follow the same process, including differences between different change classficiations i.e. standard, normal or emergency.
Example response Design:
Both applications have been developed by third party vendors. As such version changes are made by the third party development companies and version upgrades are released every 6 months by the vendors, with patches released occasionally. Management run both applications 2 versions behing. These changes are logged by management and tested and approved prior to release following the standard change process. 

Configuration changes are made by the application owner in IT based on a request from the business. These follow the same standard change process. 

The CAB is required to approve changes and typically UAT is performed by the requestor for the change or their delegate
Tailored Procedure - Implementation / Ev: Inspect system configuration and/or user access to determine management has appropriately segregated access to development, test and production or has other controls in place to achieve the same objective
Key Considerations for Implementation:
1. The environment for development, test, and production should be segregated.

2. Access should be restricted to ensure only select users are able to make changes to configuration or code.
Example Response implementation:
PwC Confirmed through validating applications are third party developed and procedures performed over Privileged access to confirm accounts that can make changes to settings.
 
 We inspected the application and confirmed the environment are segregated using URLs. 
 1. Production: app.com
 2. Test : app.test.com
 3. Development : app.dev.com

Testing Criteria: How emergency change criteria has been defined and requirements around the timing of required testing and promotion approvals (e.g., within 48 hours of a change being promoted into production).
Key Considerations for Design:
1. There should be a clear definition of requirement for emergency 
 
2. Emergency changes should be subject to test and approval
Example response Design: The 'Change enablement policy' and ' change management standard operating procedures' set out criteria for an emergency change. A change is considered an emergency if it is proposed to address an issue with system functionalyt which would otherwise prevent the operation of a core business process. Verbal approval must be sought from CAB or the CIO prior to deployment testing and approval of these changes is still required, with the policy dictating that all change documentation should be in place within 72 hours of the change being implemented in production. This includes testing, approval from process owners and retrospective approval from the CAB (which includes the CIO) via email.
Tailored Procedure - Implementation / Ev: For one emergency change inspect the criteria in the policy and compare to an emergency change logged in the period to understand how the criteria are defined and met.
Key Considerations for Implementation:
1. There should be a clear definition of requirement for emergency 
 
2. Emergency changes should be subject to test and approval
Example Response implementation:
We inspected a copy of change ticket XYZ456 for an emergency change raised by the financial controller.
 
 It was confirmed that the change met the criteria of an emergency change with issues on reporting functionality. This was confirmed by the application manager with verbal approval sought from the CIO.
 
 Within the change ticket, the junior developer was assigned to develop the change which was implemented by the application manager on XX/XX/2022.
 
 After the change was implemented, testing was retrospectively completed to confirm that there were no issues with functionality, with results documented and attached to the change ticket.
 
 Approval was retrospectively provided by the process owner on XX/XX/2022. In addition, the CAB convened to review change documentation and approved this emergency change on XX/XX/2022, 48 hours after implementation. This was logged in the attached change ticket.

Testing Criteria: How the control operator determines the appropriate level of testing required (e.g., unit, integration, regression and user acceptance testing) was performed. The nature and extent of testing may vary based on the scope and complexity of the change.
Key Considerations for Design: 1. The policy or procedure document should have a method for determining the level of testing applicable to each type/classification of change
Example response Design:
The level of testing required is based on the nature of the change, the specific code/configuration subject to change and expected functionality. There is also consideration of any dependencies and wider implications of the change.
 
 Based on this, an itemised test plan is developed.
Tailored Procedure - Implementation / Ev: For one change inspect / observe the relevant evidence retained.
Key Considerations for Implementation:
1. A test plan should be developed
 
2. Test should be performed before the change is implemented
Example Response implementation:
For the change sampled under ticket ABC123, we inspected evidence of the test plan documented and attached within the change ticket.
 
 The test plan was tailored to the change, with specific elements of functionality and data points identified for testing.
 
 Testing was completed with results documented in the test plan. UAT was signed off by the tester within the AR team, with explanations of their procedures and the results documented.
 
 No issues were identified in testing.

Testing Criteria: How the control operator creates test cases, scripts and plans to achieve an appropriate level of testing.
Key Considerations for Design:
1. Testing scripts are formalised with detail of testers involved, results and dates. 

2. Test scripts should be signed off or approved by someone other than the tester, who holds a position senior enough to provide approval. 

3. Failed test scripts should be rejected and the change should not proceed until testing matters have been resolved.
Example response Design:
Test cases are created with business users asked to utilise the functionality in the test environment with specific procedures recorded based on input from the development team and process owner. 

The test logs the results of each test and any issues noted in the test scripts are recorded for resolution.
Tailored Procedure - Implementation / Ev:
Inspect tests scripts which detail the tester, results, date/timestamps

Evidence of sign off/approval of the test scripts should be provided
Key Considerations for Implementation:
1. Testing evidence should be documented with sufficient detail (Tester details, documentation, dates and timestamps, results)

2. Review and approval should be documented by an individual who is authorised
Example Response implementation: PwC inspected the testing evidence associated with change ABC123. It was noted that UAT testing was performed on XX/XX/XX by Mr John (Application Support Team) and passed without any deviations. This was then reviewed and signed off by Mr Smith on the XX/XX/XX, in line with the testing requirements for a standard change.

1. Approvers should be in line with defined approval pre-requisits, i.e. sufficient seniority and experience or position.

2. Sufficiency of approval should depend on the change type and match the requirements of the change

Testing Criteria: How the control operator compares the version to be promoted to that approved for promotion (e.g. manual comparison or through version control software) and verifies it is promoted to production accurately.
Key Considerations for Design:
1. Understand how version protocols are identifed within the the change ticket
2. Identify any retrospective procedures to ensure that the change implemented into production is in line within the developed change
3. Identify any post implementation checks performed and procedures that occurr if the change is not line with the developed change.
Example response Design:
Within the 'change enablement policy' post implementaton activities require the application support team to perform post implementation approval to validate the change is promoted to production accurately. This is achieved through performing functional testing and comparing version metadata, ensuring it matches to that of the test environment. 

Any variances would require a helpdesk ticket to be raised and follow up activities to identify the root cause and impact of the different change.
Tailored Procedure - Implementation / Ev: For one change inspect evidence of post implementation checks including the sign off and approval of such checks.
Key Considerations for Implementation: 1. Inspect sign off evidence to support post implementation checks
Example Response implementation: For the change sampled under ticket ABC123, PwC validated that post implentation approval was provided by Mrs Thomson on the XX/XX/XX, confirming that changes were promoted to the production environment as expected.
